ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar, but sometimes all the students would meet outside in various locations on campus to paint together (professor was still remote and lesson was still conducted via Zoom).
N/A
Sometimes we were asked to paint outside in groups (but still attend the lecture via zoom).
Half lecture, half painting time.

The professor was off-campus but instructed which courtyards to meet in each week when the pandemic allowed, we were still on zoom but this way we could see other people's work in-person and have some of the same subjects in our paintings.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Painting in watercolor, art analysis, writing, and learning about watercolor artists and techniques
My painting skills significantly improved, and I learned how to paint faster.
Patience
This course introduced me to watercolor and various painting techniques.
Various watercolor techniques

I learned multiple watercolor techniques, learned how to make my paintings look realistic, and learned how to use color effectively. I also learned how to use watercolor to paint in a variety of different styles. Overall, I gained a greater understanding and respect for art.

Practiced sketching, copying works and techniques, learned various styles of watercolor and how the styles changed throughout history. Learned how to analyze works of art and how to write papers about art, they were less formal than most of the first year english prompts, so it was a nice change

I learned how to not just look at a subject and copy it down onto paper, but how to capture what I want from a subject and make a piece unique to myself. It was a wonderful experience to learn this, and the skill I found most valuable is the ability to travel and paint things from the eye.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was very engaging, even during remote learning, but there was a heavier writing load than expected.

Strengths: the course encouraged painting en plein air, and so despite the virtual format, us students could still meet outside and paint together. We also got to experiment with several different styles of watercolor painting. Weaknesses: sometimes we spent too long going over the powerpoints, which led to us not having long to paint each class.
You get comfortable with how chill it is and it haunts you in the end when you skip class and homework.
Painting outdoors was very fun and interesting, but lugging around a computer to paint felt like a big burden.

A strength was that it was a good introduction into art for someone who hasn't taken an art class since grade school. I had minimal drawing and painting experience beforehand, and still enjoyed this class and was able to learn a lot. However, I do think that a weakness is the writing portion of this course. As someone who has more of a STEM background, I would have appreciated more guidance on how to write arts papers, since they were worth a significant portion of our grade. It's a fairly different writing style, and while I'm glad to have learned a new type of writing now, it was extremely difficult for me to write these papers.

strength is that painting can be a lot of fun and Van Doren is good about giving everyone compliments and critiques no matter their skill level, weakness is sometimes the 3 paintings per week feels difficult to manage when essay due dates are approaching

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There were some technical difficulties with the lecture presentations, but the painting portion of the class was very interactive and the professor frequently checked in with us throughout our painting time.
The virtual painting setup is not optimal. The art can't shine  through the camera as well.

I liked how we painted as a group on campus (socially distant). Maybe it would be nice if the instructor was taught a little better on how to upload PDFs (e.g. essays were always given back to me upside down over gmail) and how to use zoom (screen sharing wouldve been nice instead of asking us to open presentations on our own devices).

Getting the students to meet for class at various outdoor locations (even though the professor was still remote) was great. It allowed us to form a better sense of community, to get to know each other, and to learn from each other's styles of painting.

lots of fun to meet some of the students in this class, something a lot of classes could not due, it was also a great opportunity to visit different spots on campus and let me explore while I know some did not feel the need to leave their own courtyards. Van Doren is not great with zoom, but it never hindered learning or teaching

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, as long as you are ready to put in the time towards preparing weekly paintings and some essays

I love painting, so I enjoyed having this class to balance out my work since it gave me an excuse to sit outside and paint instead of working on psets or essays. However, the workload for this course can be very high since we had to do three paintings every week (plus any extra paintings the professor set), in addition to four essays over the course of the semester, so be prepared for it to take up a lot of time.
If you like to paint, sure!
Yes, watercolor is a great way to relive stress. This is a nice skill that I will carry for the rest of my life.
Yes, its very beginner friendly and open to people who appreciate art.

I would recommend this course to a student who's looking for a lower-stress class to balance out a difficult courseload. It's also a great class for someone who maybe hasn't taken an art class before.

If you enjoy art and are proficient in writing this is for you. If you are a freshman that is very timid in their writing abilities, probably look at something else, essays counted for 60% of the grade. For me, doing my paintings for the week was an opportunity to feel productive while avoiding some other monotonous psets
